column3: Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4821_4d7d387734f5643bf95af8ffc681534b755c558b/ for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-te
Fair enough, will approach it differently.\n

You could remove the `e` instead of the entire clause?

Agree that this is the wrong solution, never make catch clauses more general than they should be.
This is not exactly equivalent (haven't verified whether it matters).\n
'e' is not being used and it is faster because type of exception is not being checked.\n
But now this block will catch all types of exceptions, instead of just boost::system::system_error ones, which may not be the intention.\n
Well, it might be so but unlikely. \nJudging from the fact that boost::system_error derived from std::runtime_error it would be safe to assume that intention was to handle any abnormal condition.\n
NAK on replacing with catch (...).  We want errors like std::bad_alloc (out of memory) to either be handled by a higher-level catch or to cause an unhandled exception exit.\n
